description: From Middle English reyn, rein, from Old English reġn, from Proto-West Germanic *regn, from Proto-Germanic *regną (compare West Frisian rein, Dutch regen, German Regen, Danish and Norwegian regn), of uncertain origin. Possibly from pre-Germanic *Hréǵ-no-, from Proto-Indo-European *Hreǵ- (“to flow”) (compare Latin rigō (“wet, soak”), Lithuanian rõki (“drizzling rain”), Albanian rrjedh (“to flow, drip”)), although the consonant reflexes don't match.

entries.meaning: Condensed water falling from a cloud.
examples: We've been having a lot of rain lately.
The rains came late that year.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any matter moving or falling, usually through air, and especially if liquid or otherwise figuratively identifiable with raindrops.
(figuratively) An instance of particles or larger pieces of matter moving or falling through air.
examples: A rain of mortar fire fell on our trenches.

verbs.description: rain (third-person singular simple present rains, present participle raining, simple past and past participle rained)

entries.meaning: (impersonal) To have rain fall from the sky.
examples: Judging by the black cloud, it will rain later today.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fall as or like rain.
examples: It will rain fire and brimstone at the end of days.
The boxer rained punches on his opponent's head.

verbs.description: rain (third-person singular simple present rains, present participle raining, simple past and past participle rained)

examples: Such wondrous science in mans witt to rain.
